title: Research
text:
My research in ecosystem ecology has focused on both carbon and nitrogen cycling, primarily in northern temperate forests.

title: Digital Assets: Scrollytelling
text:
Scrollytelling example


See an example of using the closereads package to highlight the main findings from one of my recent projects, Digital Assets for Nature.
The dataset compiled for this project can be found at the Knowledge Network for Biocomplexity.

title: Visualizing Spatial Data
text:
Workshop Overview
My first workshop for EcoDataScience on visualizing spatial data. I present an overview of the sf package in R, how to add a basemap with different packages, and some other tips and tricks for improving reproducibility and efficiency in map making.






Figure 1: One of the maps created during the tutorial.

title: Rachel King
text:
Current Interests



Synthesis & Data Science

Understanding broad patterns in ecology and environmental science requires synthesizing knowledge from numerous studies that cover different ecosystems, conditions, taxonomic groups and more. I enjoy the challenge and insights that come from thinking about big questions in ecology and leveraging existing data to further our understanding of important topics.





Biodiversity and Ecosystem Functioning
I am continuously fascinated by the diversity of life on Earth and how different organisms interact to perform key ecosystem functions. My work in this area has recently focused on how tree diversity impacts tree survival and carbon storage in a tree diversity experiment, investigating the impacts of climate change on leaf litter decomposition, and identifying gaps and improvement opportunities in automated biodiversity monitoring.

title: Tidy Tuesday
text:
Tidy Tuesday
See my data viz examples from the Tidy Tuesday project in R.
When I get the chance, I use use the tidytuesdayR package to download the data, explore it, and create a visualization I post to my repository. In creating this repo, I followed this tutorial by Nicola Rennie to make a template for each week to streamline my workflow.






Figure 1

title: Prey Distribution Mapping
text:
Project Overview
There are many threatened and endangered species within California drylands, and many active efforts to conserve and restore their populations. One important component of conservation for endangered consumers, such as the Blunt-nosed Leopard Lizard, is ensuring that they have adequate prey resources. In this project, we compiled a list of prey of endangered species in California drylands, downloaded occurrence records for the prey from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility, and used these to create species distribution models for finding suitable prey habitat. These were stacked to identify hot-spots of potential prey species richness for different predators. These species distribution models, raw occurrence records, and other summary plots can be viewed interactively in the linked shiny app. The data for the app and associated paper (King et al., submitted) are availble on Zenodo: https://zenodo.org/records/10215172.


The first page of the Shiny application.

title: Rachel King  Ecologist & Data Analyst
text: Data Analyst at the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at UC Santa Barbara.
